segment.source: Build Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that support custom interactions from pen and stylus devices, including digital ink for natural writing and drawing experiences.
segment.target: Build Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that support custom interactions from pen and stylus devices, including digital ink for natural writing and drawing experiences.

segment.source: Pen and stylus interactions
segment.target: Pen and stylus interactions

segment.source: Pen and stylus interactions
segment.target: Pen and stylus interactions

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Optimize your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app design for touch input and get basic pen support by default.
segment.target: Optimize your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app design for touch input and get basic pen support by default.

segment.source: The UWP app ink platform, together with a pen device, provides a natural way to create handwritten notes, drawings, and annotations.
segment.target: The UWP app ink platform, together with a pen device, provides a natural way to create handwritten notes, drawings, and annotations.

segment.source: The platform supports capturing ink data from digitizer input, generating ink data, rendering that data as ink strokes on the output device, managing the ink data, and performing handwriting recognition.
segment.target: The platform supports capturing ink data from digitizer input, generating ink data, rendering that data as ink strokes on the output device, managing the ink data, and performing handwriting recognition.

segment.source: touchpad
segment.target: touchpad

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Input
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Input

segment.source: Windows.UI.Input.Inking
segment.target: Windows.UI.Input.Inking

segment.source: Windows.UI.Input.Inking.Core
segment.target: Windows.UI.Input.Inking.Core

segment.source: In addition to serving as a pointer device (similar to mouse and touch), a pen/stylus is typically associated with writing or drawing directly on a screen using digital ink.
segment.target: In addition to serving as a pointer device (similar to mouse and touch), a pen/stylus is typically associated with writing or drawing directly on a screen using digital ink.

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) ink platform, together with a pen/stylus device, provides a natural way to create digital handwritten notes, drawings, and annotations.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) ink platform, together with a pen/stylus device, provides a natural way to create digital handwritten notes, drawings, and annotations.

segment.source: The platform supports capturing digitizer input as ink data, generating ink data, managing ink data, rendering ink data as strokes, and converting ink to text through handwriting recognition.
segment.target: The platform supports capturing digitizer input as ink data, generating ink data, managing ink data, rendering ink data as strokes, and converting ink to text through handwriting recognition.

segment.source: In addition to capturing the basic position and movement of the pen as the user writes or draws, your app can also track and collect the varying amounts of pressure used throughout a stroke.
segment.target: In addition to capturing the basic position and movement of the pen as the user writes or draws, your app can also track and collect the varying amounts of pressure used throughout a stroke.

segment.source: This information, along with settings for pen tip shape, size, and rotation, ink color, and purpose (plain ink, erasing, highlighting, and selecting), enables you to provide user experiences that closely resemble writing or drawing on paper with a pen, pencil, or brush.
segment.target: This information, along with settings for pen tip shape, size, and rotation, ink color, and purpose (plain ink, erasing, highlighting, and selecting), enables you to provide user experiences that closely resemble writing or drawing on paper with a pen, pencil, or brush.

segment.source: Note Your app can also support ink input from other pointer-based devices, including touch digitizers and mouse devices.
segment.target: Note Your app can also support ink input from other pointer-based devices, including touch digitizers and mouse devices.

segment.source: The ink platform is very flexible.
segment.target: The ink platform is very flexible.

segment.source: It is designed to support various levels of functionality, depending on your requirements.
segment.target: It is designed to support various levels of functionality, depending on your requirements.

segment.source: There are three components to the ink platform:
segment.target: There are three components to the ink platform:

segment.source: InkCanvas - A XAML UI platform control that, by default, receives and displays all input from a pen as either an ink stroke or an erase stroke.
segment.target: InkCanvas - A XAML UI platform control that, by default, receives and displays all input from a pen as either an ink stroke or an erase stroke.

segment.source: InkPresenter - A code-behind object, instantiated along with an InkCanvas control (exposed through the InkCanvas.InkPresenter property).
segment.target: InkPresenter - A code-behind object, instantiated along with an InkCanvas control (exposed through the InkCanvas.InkPresenter property).

segment.source: This object provides all default inking functionality exposed by the InkCanvas, along with a comprehensive set of APIs for additional customization and personalization.
segment.target: This object provides all default inking functionality exposed by the InkCanvas, along with a comprehensive set of APIs for additional customization and personalization.

segment.source: IInkD2DRenderer - Enables the rendering of ink strokes onto the designated Direct2D device context of a Universal Windows app, instead of the default InkCanvas control.
segment.target: IInkD2DRenderer - Enables the rendering of ink strokes onto the designated Direct2D device context of a Universal Windows app, instead of the default InkCanvas control.

segment.source: This enables full customization of the inking experience.
segment.target: This enables full customization of the inking experience.

segment.source: Basic inking with InkCanvas
segment.target: Basic inking with InkCanvas

segment.source: For basic inking functionality, just place an InkCanvas anywhere on a page.
segment.target: For basic inking functionality, just place an InkCanvas anywhere on a page.

segment.source: The InkCanvas supports ink input only from a pen.
segment.target: The InkCanvas supports ink input only from a pen.

segment.source: The input is either rendered as an ink stroke using default settings for color and thickness, or treated as a stroke eraser (when input is from an eraser tip or the pen tip modified with an erase button).
segment.target: The input is either rendered as an ink stroke using default settings for color and thickness, or treated as a stroke eraser (when input is from an eraser tip or the pen tip modified with an erase button).

segment.source: In this example, an InkCanvas overlays a background image.
segment.target: In this example, an InkCanvas overlays a background image.

segment.source: This series of images shows how pen input is rendered by this InkCanvas control.
segment.target: This series of images shows how pen input is rendered by this InkCanvas control.

segment.source: The blank [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with a background image.
segment.target: The blank [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with a background image.

segment.source: The [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with ink strokes.
segment.target: The [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with ink strokes.

segment.source: The [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with one stroke erased.
segment.target: The [InkCanvas](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn858535) with one stroke erased.

segment.source: Note how erase operates on an entire stroke, not a portion.
segment.target: Note how erase operates on an entire stroke, not a portion.

segment.source: The inking functionality supported by the InkCanvas control is provided by a code-behind object called the InkPresenter.
segment.target: The inking functionality supported by the InkCanvas control is provided by a code-behind object called the InkPresenter.

segment.source: For basic inking, you don't have to concern yourself with the InkPresenter.
segment.target: For basic inking, you don't have to concern yourself with the InkPresenter.

segment.source: However, to customize and configure inking behavior on the InkCanvas, you must access its corresponding InkPresenter object.
segment.target: However, to customize and configure inking behavior on the InkCanvas, you must access its corresponding InkPresenter object.

segment.source: Basic customization with InkPresenter
segment.target: Basic customization with InkPresenter

segment.source: An InkPresenter object is instantiated with each InkCanvas control.
segment.target: An InkPresenter object is instantiated with each InkCanvas control.

segment.source: Along with providing all default inking behaviors of its corresponding InkCanvas control, the InkPresenter provides a comprehensive set of APIs for additional stroke customization.
segment.target: Along with providing all default inking behaviors of its corresponding InkCanvas control, the InkPresenter provides a comprehensive set of APIs for additional stroke customization.

segment.source: This includes stroke properties, supported input device types, and whether input is processed by the object or passed to the app.
segment.target: This includes stroke properties, supported input device types, and whether input is processed by the object or passed to the app.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The InkPresenter cannot be instantiated directly.
segment.target: The InkPresenter cannot be instantiated directly.

segment.source: Instead, it is accessed through the InkPresenter property of the InkCanvas.
segment.target: Instead, it is accessed through the InkPresenter property of the InkCanvas.

segment.source: Here, we configure the InkPresenter to interpret input data from both pen and mouse as ink strokes.
segment.target: Here, we configure the InkPresenter to interpret input data from both pen and mouse as ink strokes.

segment.source: We also set some initial ink stroke attributes used for rendering strokes to the InkCanvas.
segment.target: We also set some initial ink stroke attributes used for rendering strokes to the InkCanvas.

segment.source: Ink stroke attributes can be set dynamically to accommodate user preferences or app requirements.
segment.target: Ink stroke attributes can be set dynamically to accommodate user preferences or app requirements.

segment.source: Here, we let a user choose from a list of ink colors.
segment.target: Here, we let a user choose from a list of ink colors.

segment.source: We then handle changes to the selected color and update the ink stroke attributes accordingly.
segment.target: We then handle changes to the selected color and update the ink stroke attributes accordingly.

segment.source: These images shows how pen input is processed and customized by the InkPresenter.
segment.target: These images shows how pen input is processed and customized by the InkPresenter.

segment.source: the inkcanvas with default black ink strokes
segment.target: the inkcanvas with default black ink strokes

segment.source: the inkcanvas with user selected red ink strokes
segment.target: the inkcanvas with user selected red ink strokes

segment.source: The InkCanvas with default black ink strokes.
segment.target: The InkCanvas with default black ink strokes.

segment.source: The InkCanvas with user selected red ink strokes.
segment.target: The InkCanvas with user selected red ink strokes.

segment.source: To provide functionality beyond inking and erasing, such as stroke selection, your app must identify specific input for the InkPresenter to pass through unprocessed for handling by your app.
segment.target: To provide functionality beyond inking and erasing, such as stroke selection, your app must identify specific input for the InkPresenter to pass through unprocessed for handling by your app.

segment.source: Pass-through input for advanced processing
segment.target: Pass-through input for advanced processing

segment.source: By default, InkPresenter processes all input as either an ink stroke or an erase stroke.
segment.target: By default, InkPresenter processes all input as either an ink stroke or an erase stroke.

segment.source: This includes input modified by a secondary hardware affordance such as a pen barrel button, a right mouse button, or similar.
segment.target: This includes input modified by a secondary hardware affordance such as a pen barrel button, a right mouse button, or similar.

segment.source: When using these secondary affordances, users typically expect some additional functionality or a modified behavior.
segment.target: When using these secondary affordances, users typically expect some additional functionality or a modified behavior.

segment.source: In some cases, you might need to expose basic ink functionality for pens without secondary affordances (functionality not usually associated with the pen tip), other input device types, or additional functionality, or modified behavior, based on a user selection in your app's UI.
segment.target: In some cases, you might need to expose basic ink functionality for pens without secondary affordances (functionality not usually associated with the pen tip), other input device types, or additional functionality, or modified behavior, based on a user selection in your app's UI.

segment.source: To support this, InkPresenter can be configured to leave specific input unprocessed.
segment.target: To support this, InkPresenter can be configured to leave specific input unprocessed.

segment.source: This unprocessed input is then passed through to your app for processing.
segment.target: This unprocessed input is then passed through to your app for processing.

segment.source: The following code example steps through how to enable stroke selection when input is modified with a pen barrel button (or right mouse button).
segment.target: The following code example steps through how to enable stroke selection when input is modified with a pen barrel button (or right mouse button).

segment.source: For this example, we use the MainPage.xaml and MainPage.xaml.cs files to host all code.
segment.target: For this example, we use the MainPage.xaml and MainPage.xaml.cs files to host all code.

segment.source: First, we set up the UI in MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: First, we set up the UI in MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: Here, we add a canvas (below the InkCanvas) to draw the selection stroke.
segment.target: Here, we add a canvas (below the InkCanvas) to draw the selection stroke.

segment.source: Using a separate layer to draw the selection stroke leaves the InkCanvas and its content untouched.
segment.target: Using a separate layer to draw the selection stroke leaves the InkCanvas and its content untouched.

segment.source: the blank inkcanvas with an underlying selection canvas
segment.target: the blank inkcanvas with an underlying selection canvas

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml.cs, we declare a couple of global variables for keeping references to aspects of the selection UI.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml.cs, we declare a couple of global variables for keeping references to aspects of the selection UI.

segment.source: Specifically, the selection lasso stroke and the bounding rectangle that highlights the selected strokes.
segment.target: Specifically, the selection lasso stroke and the bounding rectangle that highlights the selected strokes.

segment.source: Next, we configure the InkPresenter to interpret input data from both pen and mouse as ink strokes, and set some initial ink stroke attributes used for rendering strokes to the InkCanvas.
segment.target: Next, we configure the InkPresenter to interpret input data from both pen and mouse as ink strokes, and set some initial ink stroke attributes used for rendering strokes to the InkCanvas.

segment.source: Most importantly, we use the InputProcessingConfiguration property of the InkPresenter to indicate that any modified input should be processed by the app.
segment.target: Most importantly, we use the InputProcessingConfiguration property of the InkPresenter to indicate that any modified input should be processed by the app.

segment.source: Modified input is specified by assigning InputProcessingConfiguration.RightDragAction a value of InkInputRightDragAction.LeaveUnprocessed.
segment.target: Modified input is specified by assigning InputProcessingConfiguration.RightDragAction a value of InkInputRightDragAction.LeaveUnprocessed.

segment.source: We then assign listeners for the unprocessed PointerPressed, PointerMoved, and PointerReleased events passed through by the InkPresenter.
segment.target: We then assign listeners for the unprocessed PointerPressed, PointerMoved, and PointerReleased events passed through by the InkPresenter.

segment.source: All selection functionality is implemented in the handlers for these events.
segment.target: All selection functionality is implemented in the handlers for these events.

segment.source: Finally, we assign listeners for the StrokeStarted and StrokesErased events of the InkPresenter.
segment.target: Finally, we assign listeners for the StrokeStarted and StrokesErased events of the InkPresenter.

segment.source: We use the handlers for these events to clean up the selection UI if a new stroke is started or an existing stroke is erased.
segment.target: We use the handlers for these events to clean up the selection UI if a new stroke is started or an existing stroke is erased.

segment.source: the inkcanvas with default black ink strokes
segment.target: the inkcanvas with default black ink strokes

segment.source: We then define handlers for the unprocessed PointerPressed, PointerMoved, and PointerReleased events passed through by the InkPresenter.
segment.target: We then define handlers for the unprocessed PointerPressed, PointerMoved, and PointerReleased events passed through by the InkPresenter.

segment.source: All selection functionality is implemented in these handlers, including the lasso stroke and the bounding rectangle.
segment.target: All selection functionality is implemented in these handlers, including the lasso stroke and the bounding rectangle.

segment.source: the selection lasso
segment.target: the selection lasso

segment.source: To conclude the PointerReleased event handler, we clear the selection layer of all content (the lasso stroke) and then draw a single bounding rectangle around the ink strokes encompassed by the lasso area.
segment.target: To conclude the PointerReleased event handler, we clear the selection layer of all content (the lasso stroke) and then draw a single bounding rectangle around the ink strokes encompassed by the lasso area.

segment.source: the selection bounding rect
segment.target: the selection bounding rect

segment.source: Finally, we define handlers for the StrokeStarted and StrokesErased InkPresenter events.
segment.target: Finally, we define handlers for the StrokeStarted and StrokesErased InkPresenter events.

segment.source: These both just call the same cleanup function to clear the current selection whenever a new stroke is detected.
segment.target: These both just call the same cleanup function to clear the current selection whenever a new stroke is detected.

segment.source: Here's the function to remove all selection UI from the selection canvas when a new stroke is started or an existing stroke is erased.
segment.target: Here's the function to remove all selection UI from the selection canvas when a new stroke is started or an existing stroke is erased.

segment.source: Custom ink rendering
segment.target: Custom ink rendering

segment.source: By default, ink input is processed on a low-latency background thread and rendered "wet" as it is drawn.
segment.target: By default, ink input is processed on a low-latency background thread and rendered "wet" as it is drawn.

segment.source: When the stroke is completed (pen or finger lifted, or mouse button released), the stroke is processed on the UI thread and rendered "dry" to the InkCanvas layer (above the application content and replacing the wet ink).
segment.target: When the stroke is completed (pen or finger lifted, or mouse button released), the stroke is processed on the UI thread and rendered "dry" to the InkCanvas layer (above the application content and replacing the wet ink).

segment.source: The ink platform enables you to override this behavior and completely customize the inking experience by custom drying the ink input.
segment.target: The ink platform enables you to override this behavior and completely customize the inking experience by custom drying the ink input.

segment.source: Custom drying requires an IInkD2DRenderer object to manage the ink input and render it to the Direct2D device context of your Universal Windows app, instead of the default InkCanvas control.
segment.target: Custom drying requires an IInkD2DRenderer object to manage the ink input and render it to the Direct2D device context of your Universal Windows app, instead of the default InkCanvas control.

segment.source: By calling ActivateCustomDrying (before the InkCanvas is loaded), an app creates an InkSynchronizer object to customize how an ink stroke is rendered dry to a SurfaceImageSource or VirtualSurfaceImageSource.
segment.target: By calling ActivateCustomDrying (before the InkCanvas is loaded), an app creates an InkSynchronizer object to customize how an ink stroke is rendered dry to a SurfaceImageSource or VirtualSurfaceImageSource.

segment.source: For example, an ink stroke could be rasterized and integrated into application content instead of as a separate InkCanvas layer.
segment.target: For example, an ink stroke could be rasterized and integrated into application content instead of as a separate InkCanvas layer.

segment.source: For a full example of this functionality, see the Complex ink sample .
segment.target: For a full example of this functionality, see the Complex ink sample .

segment.target: Store ink stroke data in a Graphics Interchange Format (GIF) file using embedded Ink Serialized Format (ISF) metadata.
